author: cronoss5638
content: Other than the 'minimum issuance policy' what is the motivation for allowing potential deflation to happen because of this EIP?

author: agusx1211
content: It solidifies the monetary policy, and it compensates Ethereum holders for being diluted to pay for security. Holders subsidise the block reward when the fee market is low, but they get "paid" when the fee market is high.

author: cronoss5638
content: Yes, I understand that rhetoric. I'm just curious on why there is such an disproportionate emphasis on only one use-case of ETH: 'holding' (store of value). Holders can already stake for additional pay. The burn could be capped at the value of the block reward (the rest, if any, could go to a developers fund, for example). This negates the risk of structural deflation, which could impair another use-case of ETH: as a real-world currency.

author: sky.cactus
content: A censorship resistant/decentralized developer fund is non-trivial.  Who would get it?  How would it be managed?  Who is in charge of allocation?   Who has the keys to it?

author: sky.cactus
content: Separately, I don't know that we have any good examples in history of a currency failing as a currency because it was deflationary?

author: cronoss5638
content:
Yes, those are hard to find. Classical currencies, tied to central banks, don't really see structural deflation due to policy (and cryptos usually fail due to other, more severe, reasons...). I was thinking more along the lines of others adopting ETH. Would a mortgage in ETH be viable? (especially if salaries are still paid in fiat). If a country decides to adopt a deflationary ETH (I know, pipe dream, but I'm optimistic) would they not fall victim to the paradox of thrift?
I guess it depends on which school of economics you subscribe to. I believe excluding deflation would ease adoption.

author: cronoss5638
content: I agree that is not a trivial problem.

author: cronoss5638
content:
What also bothers me regarding this EIP is that it not just minimizes paying for security, but also punishes actual users.
If fees are consistently high you have deflation. Does that mean that the network is now paying a negative amount of ETH for security? No. The difference comes from those actual users. If you spent ETH in such a market you're essentially punished thrice. Once because you now have less ETH. Twice because you had to pay a fee for using the network. And thrice because that spent ETH (and fee!) is now automatically worth more. Seems unhealthy.
